s0002: His mother was a woman of the Youtai clan, named Jiang Yuan.
s0003: Jiang Yuan was the primary consort of Emperor Ku.
s0004: Jiang Yuan went out into the wilderness and saw giant footprints. Her heart was filled with joy; she wished to step on them, and when she did, her body moved as if she were pregnant.
s0005: She carried the child to term and gave birth to a son, but considered it an ill omen and abandoned him in a narrow alley. Horses and oxen passing by all avoided stepping on him.
s0006: She moved him to the forest, but by chance met many woodcutters who moved him away.
s0007: She abandoned him in a ditch on the ice, but flying birds covered and protected him with their wings.
s0008: Jiang Yuan considered this divine and took him in to raise and care for him.
s0009: Initially she wanted to abandon him, so she named him Qi.
s0010: When Qi grew up, he was skilled at sowing seeds. The people followed his example.
